comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Vincent is beginning to age and shows all the hallmarks of prosperity.  The ladies all look well turned out, funny that the four aprons and collars are different.

comment.author: 72025404@N08
comment._content: look at that! this is a great portrait, very high quality! interesting remark of mogey, by the way!

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
Ah when nurses looked like nurses are supposed to look!
I have an 1930s Dutch nurses uniform, much like it.
My grandmothers wore it as well.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Did the nurses' collar shapes signify anything?  (My mother was a nurse; in her era the shape of the nurse's cap reflected where she was trained.)

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I see what you mean about the David Suchet/Poirot resemblance, Carol.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Ooh, they are different! Marking the difference between nurses and sisters and matrons?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/72025404@N08] Yes, [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mogey/] is dead right! Not at all convinced that such fancy shoes were regulation issue, so must have been for photo day...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/11418107@N02] I'm thinking ranks - nurse/sister/matron, etc.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] But a happy Poirot, when his "leetle grey cells" have triumphed over some dastardly murderer!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content: I think sisters and matrons would have had belts with silver filigree buckles, wouldn't they?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: No Carol, I would think marking the schools of nursing they came from.  I had noticed the shoes but put them down to a special occasion or announcement/visit.

comment.author: 8087163@N05
comment._content: When my wife qualified she was awarded a silver filigree buckle but that was more of a 'dress uniform' thing than a regular piece of the uniform.  Student and staff nurses wore simple head pieces and ward sisters wore more ornate, frilly headdresses occasionally leading to 'frillyitus' or delusions of grandeur!

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content: Well they're all wonderful people, I don't know where we would be without them.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jack_falstaff] Many of us would be dead.

comment.author: 41996436@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hab3045] Too true.... I'm one of them.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jack_falstaff] Me too, I owe my life to nurses, doctors and one atomic bomb, as horrible that may sound.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Oh grand, good point on the Schools of Nursing!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pmcdonnell] That Frillyitus is incurable, I've heard.
